description: From Latin pathognomicus, from Hellenistic Ancient Greek παθογνωμικός (pathognōmikós), shortened form of παθογνωμονικός (pathognōmonikós, “pathognomonic”).

adjectives.description: pathognomic (comparative more pathognomic, superlative most pathognomic)

entries.meaning: (now rare) Related to how emotions are manifested, especially in the face. [from 17th c.]
(medicine) Indicative of a specific disease, disorder etc.; pathognomonic. [from 17th c.]
examples: In 1859, Alfred Garrod (1819–1907) devised a simple chemical test pathognomic for gout.

entries.meaning: (medicine, obsolete) An indication of a specific disease or disorder. [17th–19th c.]
